div.p: The famous tragedy of the rich Jew of Malta. As it was played before the King and Queen, in his majesty's theatre at white-hall, by her majesty's servants at the cockpit.
London printed by I. B. for Nicholas Vavasour, and are to be sold at his shop in the inner-temple, near the church. 1633.

div.head: To my worthy friend, Mr. Thomas Hammon, of Gray's inn, etc.
div.p:
This play, composed by so worthy an author as Mr. Marlo; and the part of the Jew presented by so unimitable an actor as Mr. Allin, being in this later age commended to the stage: as I ushered it unto the court, and presented it to the cockpit, with these prologues and epilogues here inserted, so now being newly brought to the press, I was loath it should be published without the ornament of an epistle; making choice of you unto whom to devote it; than whom (Of all those gentlemen and acquaintance, within the compass of my long knowledge) there is none more able to tax
ignorance, or attribute right to merit. Sir, you have been pleased to grace some of mine own works with your courteous patronage; I hope this will not be the worse accepted, because commended by me; over whom, none can claim more power or privilege than yourself. I had no better a newyears gift to present you with; receive it therefore as a continuance of that inviolable obligement, by which, he rests still engaged; who as he ever hath, shall always remain,

div.head: The prologue spoken at court.
div.l: Gracious and great, that we so boldly dare,
( 'Mongst other plays that now in fashion are)
To present this; written many years ago,
And in that age, thought second unto none;
We humbly crave your pardon: we pursue
The story of a rich and famous Jew
Who lived in Malta: you shall find him still,
In all his projects, a sound Machiavel;
And that's his character: he that hath passed
So many censures, is now come at last
To have your princely ears, grace you him; than
You crown the action, and renown the pen.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: It is our fear (Dread sovereign) we have been
Too tedious; neither can't be less than sin
To wrong your princely patience: if we have,
(Thus low dejected) we your pardon crave:
And if ought here offend your ear or sight,
We only act, and speak, what others write.

div.head: The prologue to the stage, at the cockpit.
div.l: We 〈…〉 pass this stage,
But by the best ofMarlo. poets in that age
The Malta-jew had being, and was made;
And he, then by the best ofAllin. actors played:
In hero and Leander, one did gain
A lasting memory: in Tamburlaine,
This Jew, with others many: th' other man
The attribute of peerless, being a man
Whom we may rank with (Doing no one wrong)
Proteus for shapes, and Roseius for a tongue,
So could he speak, so vary; nor is't hate
To merit: inPerkins. him who doth personate
Our Jew this day, nor is it his ambition
To exceed, or equal, being of condition
More modest; this is all that he intends,
(And that too, at the urgence of some friends)
To prove his best, and if none here gainsay it,
The part he hath studied, and intends to play it.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: In graving, with Pygmalion to contend;
Or painting, with Apelles; doubtless the end
Must be disgrace: our actor did not so,
He only aimed to go, but not out go.
Nor think that this day any prize was played,
Here were no bets at all, no wagers laid;
All the ambition that his mind doth swell,
Is but to hear from you, (By me) 'twas well.

div.head: The Jew of Malta.

sp.speaker: Machevil.
sp.l: Albeit the world think Machiavel is dead,
Yet was his soul but flown beyond the Alps,
And now the Guize is dead, is come from France
To view this land, and frolic with his friends.
To some perhaps my name is odious,
But such as love me, guard me from their tongues,
And let them know that I am Machiavel,
And weigh not men, and therefore not men's words:
Admired I am of those that hate me most.
Though some speak openly against my books,
Yet will they read me, and thereby attain
To Peter's chair: and when they cast me off;
Are poisoned by my climing followers.
I count religion but a childish toy,
And hold there is no sin but ignorance.
Birds of the air will tell of murders past;
I am ashamed to hear such fooleries:
Many will talk of title to a crown.
What right had Caesar to the empire?
Might first made Kings, and laws were then most sure
When like the Drancus they were writ in blood.
Hence comes it, that a strong built citadel
Commands much more than letters can import:
Which maxim had Phaleris observed,
He'd never bellowed in a brazen bull
Of great ones envy; o'th poor petty wites,
Let me be envied and not pitied!
But whither am I bound, I come not, ay,
To read a lecture here in Britain,
But to present the tragedy of a Jew,
Who smiles to see how full his bags are crammed
Which money was not got without my means.
I crave but this, grace him as he deserves,
And let him not be entertained the worse
Because he favours me.

div.stage: Enter Barabas in his countinghouse, with heaps of gold before him.

sp.speaker: Jew,
sp.l: So that of thus much that return was made:
And of the third part of the Persian ships,
There was the venture summed and satisfied.
As for those Samintes, and the men of Uz,
That bought my Spanish oils, and wines of Greece,
Here have I pursed their paltry silverlings.
Fie; what a trouble 'tis to count this trash.
Well fare the Arabians, who so richly pay,
The things they traffic for with wedge of gold,
Whereof a man may easily in a day
Tell that which may maintain him all his life.
The needy groom that never fingered groat,
Would make a miracle of thus much coin:
But he whose steel-barred coffers are crammed full,
And all his life time hath been tired,
Wearying his fingers ends with telling it,
Would in his age be loath to labour so,
And for a pound to sweat himself to death:
Give me the merchants of the Indian mines,
That trade in mettle of the purest mould;
The wealth Moor, that in the Eastern rocks
without control can pick his riches up,
And in his house heap pearl like pebble-stones:
Receive them free, and sell them by the weight,
Bags of fiery opals, saphires, amatists,
Jacints, hard Topas, grass-green emeralds,
Beauteous rubies, sparkling diamonds,
And seld-seen costly stones of so great price,
As one of them indifferently rated,
And of a carat of this quantity,
May serve in peril of calamity
To ransom great Kings from captivity.
This is the ware wherein consists my wealth:
And thus methinks should men of judgement frame
Their means of traffic from the vulgar trade,
And as their wealth increaseth, so enclose
Infinite in a little room.
But now how stands the wind?
Into what corner peers my halcyon's bill?
Ha, to the East? yes: see how stands the vanes?
East and by-south: why then I hope my ships
I sent for Egypt and the bordering isles
Are gotten up by Nilus' winding banks:
Mine argosy from Alexandria,
Loaden with spice and silks, now under sail,
Are smoothly gliding down by Candy shore
To Malta, through our Mediterranean sea.
But who comes hear? How now.

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.l: Barabas, thy ships are safe,
Riding in Malta Rhode: and all the merchants
With other merchandise are safe arrived,
And have sent me to know whether yourself
Will come and custom them.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: The ships are safe thou sayest, and richly fraught.

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.l: They are.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Why then go bid them come ashore,
And bring with them their bills of entry:
I hope our credit in the customhouse
Will serve as well as I were present there.
Go send 'em threescore camels, thirty mules,
And twenty waggons to bring up the ware.
But art thou master in a ship of mine,
And is thy credit not enough for that?

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.l: The very custom barely comes to more
Than many merchants of the town are worth,
And therefore far exceeds my credit, sir.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Go tell 'em the Jew of Malta sent thee, man.
Tush, who amongst 'em knows not Barabas?

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.l: I go.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: So then, there's somewhat come.
Sirrah, which of my ships art thou master off?

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.l: Of the Speranza, sir.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: And sawest thou not mine argosy at Alexandria
Thou couldst not come from Egypt, or by Caire
But at the entry there into the sea,
Where Nilus pays his tribute to the main,
Thou needs must sail by Alexandria.

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.l: I neither saw them, nor enquired of them.
But this we heard some of our seamen say,
They wondered how you durst with so much wealth
Trust such a crazed vessel, and so far.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Tush; they are wise, I know her and her strength:
By go, go thou thy ways, discharge thy ship,
And bid my factor bring his loading in.
And yet I wonder at this argosy,

sp.speaker: 2. Merchant
sp.l: Thine argosy from Alexandria,
Know Barabas doth ride in Malta Rhode.
Laden with riches, and exceeding store
Of Persian silks, of gold, and orient pearl:

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: How chance you came not with those other ship
That sailed by Egypt?

sp.speaker: 2 merchant
sp.l: Sir we saw 'em not.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Belike they coasted round by Candy shore
about their oils, or other businesses.
But 'twas ill done of you to come so far
Without the aid or conduct of their ships.

sp.speaker: 2. Merchant
sp.l: Sir, we were wafted by a Spanish fleet
That never left us till within a league,
That had the galleys of the Turk in chase.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: O they were going up to Sicily: well, go
And bid the merchants and my men dispatch
And come ashore, and see the fraught discharged.

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.l: I go. Exit.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Thus trolls our fortune in by land and sea,
And thus are we on every side enriched:
These are the blessings promised to the Jews,
And herein was old Abraham's happiness:
What more may heaven do for earthly man
Then thus to pour out plenty in their laps,
Ripping the bowels of the earth for them,
Making the sea their servants, and the winds
To drive their substance with successful blasts?
Who hateth me but for my happiness?
Or who is honoured now but for his wealth?
Rather had I a Jew be hated thus,
Then pitied in a Christian poverty:
For I can see no fruits in all their faith,
But malice, falsehood, and excessive pride,
Which methinks fits not their profession.
Happily some hapless man hath conscience,
And for his conscience lives in beggary.
They say we are a scattered nation:
I cannot tell, but we have scambled up
More wealth by far then those that brag of faith.
There's Kirriab Jairim, the great Jew of Greece,
Obed in Bairseth, Nones in Portugal,
Myself in Malta, some in Italy,
Many in France, and wealthy every one:
Ay, wealthier far than any christian.
I must confess we come not to be Kings:
that's not our fault: alas, our number's few,
And crowns come either by succession
Or urged by force; and nothing violent,
Oft have I heard tell, can be permanent.
Give us a peaceful rule, make Christians Kings,
That thirst so much for principality.
I have no charge, nor many children,
But one sole daughter, whom I hold as dear
As Agamemnon did his Iphigen:
And all I have is hers. But who comes here?
Tush, tell not me 'twas done of policy.
Come therefore let us go to Barabas;
For he can counsel best in these affairs;
And here he comes.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Why how now countrymen?
Why flock you thus to me in multitudes?
What accident's betided to the Jews?
A fleet of warlike galleys, Barabas,
Are come from Turkey, and lie in our rhode:
And they this day sit in the counsel-house
To entertain them and their embassy.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Why let 'em come, so they come not to war;
Or let 'em war, so we be conquerors:
Nay, let 'em combat, conquer, and kill all,Aside.
So they spare me, my daughter, and my wealth.
Were it for confirmation of a league,
They would not come in warlike manner thus.
I fear their coming will afflict us all.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Fond men, what dream you of their multitudes?
What need they treat of peace that are in league?
The Turks and those of Malta are in league.
Tut, tut, there is some other matter in't.
Why, Barabas, they come for peace or war.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Happily for neither, but to pass along
Towards Venice by the Adriatic sea;
With whom they have attempted many times,
but never could effect their stratagem.
And very wisely said, it may be so.
But there's a meeting in the senate-house,
And all the Jews in Malta must be there.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Umh; all the Jews in Malta must be there?
Ay, like enough, why then let every man
Provide him, and be there for fashion-sake.
If any thing shall there concern our state
Assure yourselves I'll look unto myself. Aside,
I know you will; well brothers let us go.
Let's take our leaves; farewell good Barabas.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Do so; farewell Zaareth, farewell Temainte.
And Barabas now search this secret out.
Summon thy senses, call thy wits together:
These silly men mistake the matter clean.
Long to the Turk did Malta contribute;
Which tribute all in policy, I fear,
The Turks have let increase to such a sum,
As all the wealth of Malta cannot pay;
And now by that advantage thinks, belike,
To seize upon the town: ay, that he seeks.
Howe'er the world go, I'll make sure for one,
And seek in time to intercept the worst,
Warily guarding that which I ha' got.
Ego mihimet sum semper proximas.
Why let 'em enter, let 'em take the town.

div.stage: Enter governors of Malta, knight's me● by bassoes of the Turk; Calymath.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Now bassoes, what demand you at our hands?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Know knights of Malta, that we came from Rhodes
From Cyprus, Candy, and those other isles
That lie betwixt the Mediterranean seas.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: What's Cyprus, Candy, and those other isles
To us, or Malta? What at our hands demand ye?

sp.speaker: Calim.
sp.l: The ten years tribute that remains unpaid.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Alas, my lord, the sum is overgreat,
I hope your highness will consider us.

sp.speaker: Calim.
sp.l: I wish, grave governors 'twere in my power
To favour you, but 'tis my father's cause,
Wherein I may not, nay I dare not dally.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Then give us leave, great Selim-calymath.

sp.speaker: Caly.
sp.l: Stand all aside, and let the knights determine,
And send to keep our galleys under-sail,
For happily we shall not tarry here:
Now governors how are you resolved?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Thus: since your hard conditions are such
That you will needs have ten years tribute past,
We may have time to make collection
Amongst the inhabitants of Malta for't.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: That's more than is in our commission.

sp.speaker: Caly.
sp.l: What Callapine a little courtesy.
Let's know their time, perhaps it is not long;
And 'tis more kingly to obtain by peace
Then to enforce conditions by constraint.
What respite ask you governors?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: But a month.

sp.speaker: Caly.
sp.l: We grant a month, but see you keep your promise.
Now launch our galleys back again to sea,
Where we'll attend the respite you have ta'en,
And for the money send our messenger.
Farewell great governors, and brave knights of Malta.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: And all good fortune wait on Calymath.
Go one and call those Jews of Malta hither:
Were they not summoned to appear today.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: They were, my lord, and here they come.

sp.speaker: 1 knight.
sp.l: Have you determined what to say to them?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Yes, give me leave, and Hebrwes now come near.
From the emperor of Turkey is arrived
Great Selim-calymath, his highness' son,
To levy of us ten years tribute past,
Now then here know that it concerneth us:

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Then good my lord, to keep your quiet still,
your lordship shall do well to let them have it.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Soft Barabas, there's more longs to't than so.
To what this ten years tribute will amount
That we have cast, but cannot compass it
By reason of the wars, that robbed our store;
And therefore are we to request your aid.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Alas, my lord, we are no soldiers:
And what's our aid against so great a prince?

sp.speaker: 1 knight
sp.l: Tut, Jew, we know thou art no soldier;
Thou art a merchant, and a monied man,
And 'tis thy money, Barabas, we seek.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: How, my lord, my money?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Thine and the rest.
For to be short, amongst you 'tmust be had,

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Alas, my lord, the most of us are poor.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Then let the rich increase your portions:

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Are strangers with your tribute to be taxed?

sp.speaker: 2 knight
sp.l: Have strangers leave with us to get their wealth?
Then let them with us contribute.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: How, equally?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: No, Jew, like infidels.
For through our sufferance of your hateful lives,
Who stand accursed in the sight of heaven,
These taxes and afflictions are befallen,
And therefore thus we are determined;
Read there the articles of our decrees.

sp.speaker: Reader.
sp.l: First, the tribute money of the Turks shall all be
Levied amongst the Jews, and each of them to pay one
Half of his estate.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: How, half his estate? I hope you mean not mine.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Read on.

sp.speaker: Read.
sp.l: Secondly, he that denies to pay, shall straight become
A christian.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: How a christian? Hum, what's here to do?

sp.speaker: Read.
sp.l: Lastly, he that denies this, shall absolutely lose all he has.

sp.speaker: All 3 Jews.
sp.l: O my lord we will give half.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: O earth-mettled villains, and no Hebrews born!
And will you basely thus submit yourselves
To leave your goods to their arbitrament?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Why Barabas wilt thou be christened?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No, governor, I will be no convertite.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Then pay thy half.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Why know you what you did by this device?
Half of my substance is a city's wealth.
Governor, it was not got so easily;
Nor will I part so slightly therewithal.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Sir, half is the penalty of our decree,
Either pay that, or we will seize on all.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Corpo di deo; stay, you shall have half,
Let me be used but as my brothers are.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: No, Jew, thou hast denied the articles,
And now it cannot be recalled.

sp.speaker: Bar,
sp.l: Will you then steal my goods?
Is theft the ground of your religion?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: No, Jew, we take particularly thine
To save the ruin of a multitude:
And better one want for a common good,
Than many perish for a private man:
Yet Barabas we will not banish thee,
But here in Malta, where thou gotst thy wealth,
Live still; and if thou canst, get more.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Christians; what, or how can I multiply?
Of naught is nothing made.

sp.speaker: 1 knight.
sp.l: From naught at first thou canst to little wealth,
From little unto more, from more to most:
If your first curse fall heavy on thy head,
And make thee poor and scorned of all the world,
'Tis not our fault, but thy inherent sin.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What? bring you scripture to confirm your wrong?
Preach me not out of my possessions.
Some Jews are wicked, as all Christians are:
But say the tribe that I descended of
Were all in general cast away for sin,
Shall I be tried by their transgression?
The man that dealeth righteously shall live:
And which of you can charge me otherwise?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Out wretched Barabas, shamest thou not thus
To justify thyself, as if we knew not
Thy profession? If thou rely upon thy righteousness,
Be patient and thy riches will increase.
Excess of wealth is cause of covetousness:
And covetousness, o 'tis a monstrous sin.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ay, but theft is worse: tush, take not from me then,
For that is theft; and if you rob me thus,
I must be forced to steal and compass more.

sp.speaker: 1 knight
sp.l: Grave governors, list not to his exclaims:
Convert his mansion to a nunnery,Enter officers.
His house will harbour many holy nuns.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: It shall be so: now officers have you done?

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Ay, my lord, we have seized upon the goods
And wares of Barabas, which being valued
Amount to more than all the wealth in Malta.
And of the other we have seized half.
Then we'll take order for the residue.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Well then my lord, say, are you satisfied?
You have my goods, my money, and my wealth,
My ships, my store, and all that I enjoyed;
And having all, you can request no more;
Unless your unrelenting flinty hearts
Suppress all pity in your stony breasts,
And now shall move you to bereave my life.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: No, Barabas, to stain our hands with blood
Is far from us and our profession.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Why I esteem the injury far less,
To take the lives of miserable men,
Then be the causers of their misery,
You have my wealth the labour of my life,
The comfort of mine age, my children's hope,
And therefore never distinguish of the wrong.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Content thee, Barabas, thou hast naught but right.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Your extreme right does me exceeding wrong:
but take it to you i'th devil's name.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Come, let us in, and gather of these goods
The money for this tribute of the Turk.

sp.speaker: 1 knight,
sp.l: 'Tis necessary that be looked unto:
For if we break our day, we break the league,
And that will prove but simple policy. Exeunt,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ay, policy? that's their profession,
And not simplicity, as they suggest.
The plagues of Egypt, and the curse of heaven,
Earth's barrenness, and all men's hatred
Inflict upon them, thou great primas motor.
And here upon my knees, striking the earth,
I ban their souls to everlasting pains
And extreme tortures of the fiery deep,
That thus have dealt with me in my distress.

sp.speaker: 1 Jew.
sp.l: O yet be patient, gentle Barabas.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: O silly brothers, born to see this day!
Why stand you thus unmoved with my laments?
Why weep you not to think upon my wrongs?
Why pine not I, and die in this distress?

sp.speaker: 1 Jew.
sp.l: Why, Barabas, as hardly can we brook
The cruel handling of ourselves in this:
Thou seest they have taken half our goods.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Why did you yield to their extortion?
You were a multitude, and I but one,
And of me only have they taken all.

sp.speaker: 1 Jew.
sp.l: Yet brother Barabas remember Job,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What tell you me of Job? I wot his wealth
Was written thus: he had seven thousand sheep,
Three thousand camels, and two hundred yoke
Of labouring oxen, and five hundred
She asses: but for every one of those,
Had they been valued at indifferent rate,
I had at home, and in mine argosy
And other ships that came from Egypt last,
As much as would have bought his beasts and him,
And yet have kept enough to live upon;
so that not he, but I may curse the day,
Thy fatal birthday, forlorn Barabas;
And henceforth wish for an eternal night,
That clouds of darkness may enclose my flesh,
And hide these extreme sorrows from mine eyes:
For only I have toiled to inherit here
The months of vanity and loss of time,
And painful nights have been appointed me.

sp.speaker: 2 Jew.
sp.l: Good Barabas be patient.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ay, I pray leave me in my patience.
You that were never possessed of wealth, are pleased with want.
But give him liberty at least to mourn,
That in a field amid his enemies,
Doth see his soldiers slain, himself disarmed,
And knows no means of his recovery:
Ay, let me sorrow for this sudden chance,
'Tis in the trouble of my spirit I speak;
Great injuries are not so soon forgotten.

sp.speaker: 1 Jew.
sp.l: Come, let us leave him in his ireful mood,
Our words will but increase his ecstasy.

sp.speaker: 2 Jew.
sp.l: On then: but trust me 'tis a misery
To see a man in such affliction:
Farewell Barabas. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ay, fare you well.
See the simplicity of these base slaves,
Who for the villains have no wit themselves,
Think me to be a senseless lump of clay
That will with every water wash to dirt:
No, Barabas is born to better chance,
And framed of finer mould then common men,
That measure naught but by the present time.
A reaching thought will search his deepest wits,
And cast with cunning for the time to come:
For evils are apt to happen every day
But whither wends my beauteous Abigal?
O what has made my lovely daughter sad?
What? woman, moan not for a little loss:
Thy father has enough in store for thee.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Not for myself, but aged Barabas:
Father, for thee lamenteth Abigail:
But I will learn to leave these fruitless tears.
And urged thereto with my afflictions,
With fierce exclaims run to the senate-house,
And in the senate reprehend them all,
And rent their hearts with tearing of my hair,
Till they reduce the wrongs done to my father.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No, Abigail, things past recovery
Are hardly cured with exclamations.
Be silent, daughter, sufferance breeds ease,
And time may yield us an occasion
Which on the sudden cannot serve the turn.
Besides, my girl, think me not all so fond
As negligently to forgo so much
Without provision for thyself and me.
Ten thousand Portuguese, besides great pearls,
Rich costly jewels, and stones infinite,
Fearing the worst of this before it fell,
I closely hid.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Where father?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: In my house my girl.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Then shall they never be seen of Barabas:
For they have seized upon thy house and wares.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: But they will give me leave once more, I trow,
To go into my house.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: That may they not:
For there I left the governor placing nuns,
Displacing me; and of thy house they mean
To make a nunnery, where none but their own sect
Must enter in; men generally barred.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: My gold, my gold, and all my wealth is gone.
You partial heavens, have I deserved this plague?
What will you thus oppose me, luckless stars,
To make me desperate in my poverty?
And knowing me impatient in distress
Think me so mad as I will hang myself,
That I may vanish o'er the earth in air,
And leave no memory that e'er I was.
No, I will live; nor loathe I this my life:
And since you leave me in the ocean thus
To sink or swim, and put me to my shifts,
I'll rouse my senses, and awake myself.
Daughter, I have it: thou perceivest the plight
Wherein these Christians have oppressed me:
Be ruled by me, for in extremity
We ought to make bar of no policy.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Father, whate'er it be to injure them
That have so manifestly wronged us,
What will not Abigal attempt?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Why so; then thus, thou toldst me they have turned my house
Into a nunnery, and some nuns are there.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: I did.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Then Abigal, there must my girl
Entreat the abbess to be entertained.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: How, as a nun?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ay, daughter, for religion
Hides many mischiefs from suspicion.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Ay, but father they will suspect me there.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Let 'em suspect, but be thou so precise
As they may think it done of holiness.
Entreat 'em fair, and give them friendly speech,
And seem to them as if thy sins were great,
Till thou hast gotten to be entertained.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Thus father shall I much dissemble.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Tush, as good dissemble that thou never meanest
As first mean truth, and then dissemble it,
A counterfeit profession is better
Than unseen hypocrisy.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Well father, say I be entertained,
What then shall follow?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: This shall follow then;
there have I hid close underneath the plank
That runs along the upper chamber floor,
The gold and jewels which I kept for thee.
But here they come; be cunning Abigal.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Then father go with me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No, Abigal, in this
It is not necessary I be seen.
For I will seem offended with thee for't.
Be close, my girl, for this must fetch my gold.

div.stage: Enter three friars and two nuns.

sp.speaker: 1 Fry.
sp.l: Sisters, we now are almost at the new made nunnery.

sp.speaker: 1 nun
sp.l: The better; for we love not to be seen:
'Tis 30 winters long since some of us
Did stray so far amongst the multitude.

sp.speaker: 1 Fry.
sp.l: But, madam, this house
And waters of this new made nunnery
Will much delight you.

sp.speaker: Nun
sp.l: It may be so: but who comes here?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Grave abbess, and you happy virgins guide,
Pity the state of a distressed maid.

sp.speaker: Abbess
sp.l: What art thou daughter?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: The hopeless daughter of a hapless Jew,
The Jew of Malta, wretched Barabas;
Sometimes the owner of a goodly house,
Which they have now turned to a nunnery.

sp.speaker: Abbess
sp.l: Well, daughter, say, what is thy suit with us?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Fearing the afflictions which my father feels,
Proceed from sin, or want of faith in us,
I'd pass away my life in penitence,
And be a novice in your nunnery,
To make atonement for my labouring soul.

sp.speaker: 1. Fry.
sp.l: No doubt, brother, but this proceedeth of the spirit.

sp.speaker: 2 Fry.
sp.l: Ay, and of a moving spirit too, brother; but come,
Let us entreat she may be entertained.

sp.speaker: Abbess
sp.l: Well, daughter, we admit you for a nun.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: First let me as a novice learn to frame
My solitary life to your straight laws,
and let me lodge where I was wont to lie,
I do not doubt by your divine precepts
And mine own industry, but to profit much.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: As much I hope as all I hid is worth.Aside.

sp.speaker: Abbess
sp.l: Come daughter, follow us.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Why how now Abigal, what mak'st thou
Amongst these hateful Christians?

sp.speaker: 1 Fry.
sp.l: Hinder her not, thou man of little faith,
For she has mortified herself.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: How, mortified I

sp.speaker: 1 Fry.
sp.l: And is admitted to the sisterhood.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Child of perdition, and thy father's shame,
What wilt thou do among these hateful fiends?
I charge thee on my blessing that thou leave
These devils, and their damned heresy.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Father give me —

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Nay back, Abigal,
And think upon the jewels and the goldWhispers to her.
The board is marked thus that covers it.
Away accursed from thy father's sight.

sp.speaker: 1 Fry.
sp.l: Barabas, although thou art in mis-belief,
And wilt not see thine own afflictions,
Yet let thy daughter be no longer blind.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Blind, friar, I wreck not thy persuasions.
The board is marked thus † that covers it;
For I had rather die, then see her thus.
Wilt thou forsake me too in my distress,
Seduced daughter, go forget not. Aside to her.
Becomes it Jews to be so credulous,
Tomorrow early I'll be at the doors. Aside to her.
No come not at me, if thou wilt be damned,
Forget me, see me not, and so be
Farewell, remember tomorrow morning. Aside.
Out, out thou wretch.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Who's this? Fair Abigal the rich Jews daughter
Become a nun, her father's sudden fall
has humbled her and brought her down to this:
Tut, she were fitter for a tale of love
Then to be tired out with orisons:
And better would she far become a-bed
Embraced in a friendly lovers arms,
Then rise at midnight to a solemn mass.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why how now don Mathias, in a dump?

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Believe me, noble Lodowick, I have seen
The strangest sight, in my opinion,
That ever I beheld.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What wast I prithee?

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: A fair young maid scarce 14 years of age,
The sweetest flower in Citherea's field,
Cropped from the pleasures of the fruitful earth,
And strangely metamorphized nun.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: But say, what was she?

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Why the rich Jews daughter.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What Barabas, whose goods were lately seized?
Is she so fair?

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: And matchless beautiful;
As had you seen her 'twould have moved your heart,
Though countermined with walls of brass, to love,
Or at the least to pity.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: And if she be so fair as you report,
'Twere time well spent to go and visit her:
How say you, shall we?

sp.speaker: Math
sp.l: I must and will, sir, there's no remedy.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: And so will I too, or it shall go hard.
Farewell Mathias.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Farewell Lodowick. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus secundus.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Thus like the sad presaging raven that tolls
The sick man's passport in her hollow beak,
And in the shadow of the silent night
Doth shake contagion from her sable wings;
Vexed and tormented runs poor Barabas
With fatal curses towards these Christians.
The incertain pleasures of swift-footed time
Have ta'en their flight, and left me in despair;
And of my former riches rests no more
But bare remembrance; like a soldier's scar,
That has no further comfort for his maim.
O thou that with a fiery pillar led'st
The sons of Israel through the dismal shades,
Light Abraham's offspring; and direct the hand
Of Abigal this night; or let the day
Turn to eternal darkness after this:
No sleep can fasten on my watchful eyes,
Nor quiet enter my distempered thoughts,
Till I have answer of my Abigal.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Now have I happily espied a time
To search the plank my father did appoint;
And here behold (Unseen) where I have found
The gold, the pearls, and jewels which he hid.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Now I remember those old women's words,
Who in my wealth would tell me winter's tales,
And speak of spirits and ghosts that glide by night
About the place where treasure hath been hid:
And now methinks that I am one of those:
For whilst I live, here lives my soul's sole hope,
And when I die, here shall my spirit walk.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Now that my father's fortune were so good
as but to be about this happy place;
'Tis not so happy: yet when we parted last,
He said he would attend me in the morn.
Then, gentle sleep, where'er his body rests,
Give charge to Morpheus that he may dream
A golden dream, and of the sudden walk,
Come and receive the treasure I have found.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Birn para todos, my ga nada no er:
As good go on, as fit so sadly thus.
But stay, what star shines yonder in the East?
The lodestar of my life, if Abigal.
Who's there?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Peace, Abigal, 'tis I.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Then father here receive thy happiness.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Hast thou'lt? Throws down bags,

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Here,
Hast thou'lt?
There's more, and more, and more.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: O my girl,
My gold, my fortune, my felicity;
Strength to my soul, death to mine enemy;
Welcome the first beginner of my bliss:
O Abigal, Abigal, that I had thee here too,
Than my desires were fully satisfied,
But I will practise thy enlargement thence:
O girl, o gold, o beauty, o my bliss!Hugs his bags

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Father, it draweth towards midnight now,
And about this time the nuns begin to wake;
To shun suspicion, therefore, let us part.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Farewell my joy, and by my fingers take
A kiss from him that sends it from his soul.
Now Phoebus open the eyelids of the day,
And for the raven wake the morning lark,
That I may hover with her in the air;
Singing o'er these, as she does o'er her young.
Hermoso Piater, de les Denirch.Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter governor, Martin del Bosco, the knights.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Now captain tell us whither thou art bound?
Whence is thy ship that anchors in our road?
And why thou cam'st ashore without our leave?

sp.speaker: Bosc.
sp.l: Governor of Malta, hither am I bound;
My ship, the flying dragon, is of Spain,
And so am I, Del-bosco is my name;
Vice-admiral unto the Catholic King.

sp.speaker: 1 knight
sp.l: 'Tis true, my lord, therefore entreat him well.

sp.speaker: Bosc.
sp.l: Our fraught is Grecians, Turks, and Afrique Moors.
For late upon the coast of Corsica,
Because we veiled not to the Spanish fleet,
Their creeping galleys had us in the chase:
But suddenly the wind began to rise,
And then we left, and took, and fought at ease:
Some have we fired, and many have we sunk;
But one amongst the rest became our prize:
The captain's slain, the rest remain our slaves,
Of whom we would make sale in Malta here.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Martin deal Bosco, I have heard of thee;
Welcome to Malta, and to all of us;
But to admit a sale of these thy Turks
We may not, nay we dare not give consent
By reason of a tributary league.

sp.speaker: 1 knight
sp.l: Del-bosco, as thou lovest and honour'st us,
Persuade our governor against the Turk;
This truce we have is but in hope of gold,
And with that sum he craves might we wage war.

sp.speaker: Bosc.
sp.l: Will knights of Malta be in league with Turks,
And buy it basely too for sums of gold?
My lord, remember that to Europ's shame,
The christian I'll of Rhodes, from whence you came,
Was lately lost, and you were stated here
To be at deadly enmity with Turk's

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Captain we know it, but our force is small:

sp.speaker: Bosc.
sp.l: What is the sum that Calymath requires?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: A hundred thousand crowns.

sp.speaker: Bosc.
sp.l: My lord and King hath title to this isle,
And he means quickly to expel you hence;
Therefore be ruled by me, and keep the gold:
I'll write unto his majesty for aid,
And not depart until I see you free.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: On this condition shall thy Turks be sold.
Go officers and set them straight in show.
Bosco, thou shalt be Malta's general;
We and our warlike knights will follow thee
Against these barbarous misbelieving Turks.

sp.speaker: Bosc.
sp.l: So shall you imitate those you succeed:
For when their hideous force environed Rhodes,
Small though the number was that kept the town,
They fought it out, and not a man survived
To bring the hapless news to Christendom.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: So will we fight it out; come, let's away:
Proud-daring Calymath, instead of gold,
We'll send the bullets wrapped in smoke and fire:
Claim tribute where thou wilt, we are resolved,
Honour is bought with blood and not with gold.Extunt

sp.speaker: 1 officer
sp.l: This is the marketplace, here let 'em stand:
Fear not their sale, for they'll be quickly bought.

sp.speaker: 2 officer
sp.l: Every ones price is written on his back,
And so much must they yield or not be sold. Ent. Bar.

sp.speaker: 1 officer
sp.l: Here comes the Jew, had not his goods been seized,
He'd give us present money for them all.

sp.speaker: Bar,
sp.l: In spite of these swine-eating Christians,
(Unchosen nation, never circumcised;
Such as poor villains were never thought upon
Till Titus and Vespasian conquered us.)
Am I become as wealthy as I was:
They hoped my daughter would ha' been a nun;
But she's at home, and I have bought a house
As great and fair as is the governors;
And there in spite of Malta will I dwell:
having Ferneze's hand, whose heart I'll have;
Ay, and his sons too, or it shall go hard.
I am not of the tribe of levy, ay,
That can so soon forget an injury.
We Jews can fawn like spaniels when we please;
And when we grin we bite, yet are our looks
As innocent and harmless as a lamb's.
I learned in Florence how to kiss my hand,
Heave up my shoulders when they call me dog,
And duck as low as any barefoot friar,
Hoping to see them starve upon a stall,
Or else be gathered for in our synagogue;
That when the offering-basin comes to me,
Even for charity I may spit into't.
Here comes don Lodowick the governor's son,
One that I love for his good father's sake.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I hear the wealthy Jew walked this way;
I'll seek him out, and so insinuate,
That I may have a sight of Abigal;
For don Mathias tells me she is fair.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Now will I show myself to have more of the serpent
Then the dove; that is, more knave than fool.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Yond walks the Jew, now for fair Abigal.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ay, ay, no doubt but she's at your command.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Barabas, thou knowest I am the governor's son.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I would you were his father too, sir, that's all the harm
I wish you: the slave looks like a hog's cheek new singed.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Whither walk'st thou Barabas?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No further: 'tis a custom held with us,
That when we speak with gentiles like to you,
We turn into the air to purge ourselves:
For unto us the promise doth belong.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Well, Barabas, canst help me to a diamond?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: O, sir, your father had my diamonds.
Yet I have one left that will serve your turn:
I mean my daughter: — but ere he shall have her
I'll sacrifice her on a pile of wood. Aside.
I ha' the poison of the city for him, and the
White leprosy.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What sparkle does it give without a foil?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: The diamond that I talk of, ne'er was foiled:
But when he touches it, it will be foiled:
Lord Lodowick, it sparkles bright and fair.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Is it square or pointed, pray let me know.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Pointed it is, good sir, — but not for you.Aside

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I like it much the better.

sp.speaker: Brr.
sp.l: So do I too.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: How shows it by night?

sp.speaker: B●r.
sp.l: Out shines Cinthia's rays:
You'll like it better far a nights than days.Aside.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: And what's the price?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Your life and if you have it. — o my lord
We will not jar about the price; come to my house
And I will give't your honour — with a vengeance.Aside

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: No, Barabas, I will deserve it first.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Good sir, your father has deserved it at my hands,
Who of mere charity and Christian ruth,
To bring me to religious purity,
And as it were in catechising sort,
To make me mindful of my mortal sins,
Against my will, and whether I would or no,
Seized all I had, and thrust me out a doors,
And made my house a place for nuns most chaste.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: No doubt your soul shall reap the fruit of it.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ay, but my lord, the harvest is far off:
And yet I know the prayers of those nuns
And holy friars, having money for their pains,
Are wondrous; and indeed do no man good:Aside.
And seeing they are not idle, but still doing,
'Tis likely they in time may reap some fruit,
I mean in fullness of perfection.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Good Barabas glance not at our holy nuns.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No, but I do it through a burning zeal,
hoping ere long to set the house a fire;
For though they do a while increase and multiply,Aside.
I'll have a saying to that nunnery.
As for the diamond, sir, I told you of,
Come home and there's no price shall make us part,
Even for your honourable father's sake.
It shall go hard but I will see your death,Aside.
But now I must be gone to buy a slave.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: And, Barabas, I'll bear thee company.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Come then, here's the marketplace; what's the price
Of this slave, 200 crowns? Do the Turk weigh so much?

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Sir, that's his price.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What, can he steal that you demand so much?
Belike he has some new trick for a purse;
And if he has, he is worth 300 plots.
So that, being bought, the town-seal might be got
To keep him for his life time from the gallows.
The session's day is critical to thieves,
And few or none scape but by being purged.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Ratest thou this Moor but at 200 plots?

sp.speaker: 1 officer
sp.l: No more, my lord.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Why should this Turk be dearer than that Moor?

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Because he is young and has more qualities.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What, hast the philosopher's stone? and thou hast,
Break my head with it, I'll forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Itha.
sp.l: No sir, I can cut and shave.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Let me see, sirrah, are you not an old shaver?

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Alas, sir, I am a very youth.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: A youth? I'll buy you, and marry you to lady vanity
If you do well.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: I will serve you, sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Some wicked trick or other. It may be under colour
Of shaving, thou'lt cut my throat for my goods.
Tell me, hast thou thy health well?

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Ay, passing well.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: So much the worse; I must have one that's sickly,
And be but for sparing victuals: 'tis not a stone of beef a day
will maintain you in these chops; let me see one
That's some what leaner.

sp.speaker: 1 officer
sp.l: Here's a leaner, how like you him?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Where was thou born?

sp.speaker: Itha.
sp.l: In trace; brought up in Arabia.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: So much the better, thou art for my turn,
An hundred crowns; I'll have him; there's the coin.

sp.speaker: 1 officer
sp.l: Then mark him, sir, and take him hence.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ay, mark him, you were best, for this is he
That by my help shall do much villainy.
My lord farewell: come sirrah you are mine.
As for the diamond it shall be yours;
I pray, sir, be no stranger at my house,
All that I have shall be at your command.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: What makes the Jew and Lodowick so private?
I fear me 'tis about fair Abigal.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Yonder comes don Mathias, let us stay;
He loves my daughter, and she holds him dear:
But I have sworn to frustrate both their hopes,
And be revenged upon the — governor.

sp.speaker: Mater.
sp.l: This Moor is comeliest, is he not? speak son.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: No, this is the better, mother, view this well.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Seem not to know me here before your mother
Lest she mistrust the match that is in hand:
When you have brought her home, come to my house;
Think of me as thy father; son farewell.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: But wherefore talked don Lodowick with you?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Tush man, we talked of diamonds, not of Abigal.

sp.speaker: Mater.
sp.l: Tell me, Mathias, is not that the Jew?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: As for the comment on the Machabees
I have it, sir, and 'tis at your command.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Yes, madam, and my talk with him was
About the borrowing of a book or two.

sp.speaker: Mater.
sp.l: Converse not with him, he is cast off from heaven.
Thou hast thy crowns, fellow, come let's away.Exeunt

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Sirrah, Jew, remember the book.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Marry will I, sir.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Come, I have made a reasonable market, let's away.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Now let me know thy name, and there withal
Thy birth, condition, and profession.

sp.speaker: Ithi.
sp.l: Faith, sir, my birth is but mean, my name's Ithimore,
My profession what you please.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Hast thou no trade? then listen to my words,
And I will teach that shall stick by thee:
First be thou void of these affections,
Compassion, love, vain hope, and heartless fear,
Be moved at nothing, see thou pity none,
But to thy self smile when the Christians moan.

sp.speaker: Ithi.
sp.l: O brave, master, I worship your nose for this.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: As for myself, I walk abroad a nights
And kill sick people groaning under walls:
Sometimes I go about and poison wells;
And now and then, to cherish Christian thieves,
I am content to lose some of my crowns;
That I may, walking in my gallery,
See 'em go pinioned along by my door.
Being young I studied physic, and began
To practise first upon the Italian;
There I enriched the priests with burials,
And always kept the sexton's arms in ure
With digging graves and ringing dead men's kneels:
And after that was I an engineer,
And in the wars 'twixt France and Germany,
Under pretence of helping Charles the fifth,
Slew friend and enemy with my stratagems.
Then after that was I an usurer,
And with extorting, cozening, forfeiting,
And tricks belonging unto brokery,
I filled the jails with bankrupts in a year,
And with young orphans planted hospitals,
And every moon made some or other mad,
And now and then one hang himself for grief,
Pinning upon his breast a long great scroll
how I with interest tormented him.
But mark how I am blessed for plaguing them,
I have as much coin as will buy the town.
But tell me now, how hast thou spent thy time?

sp.speaker: Ithi.
sp.l: Faith, master, in setting Christian villages on fire,
Chaining of eunuchs, binding galley-slaves.
One time I was an ostler in an inn,
And in the night time secretly-would I steal
To travellers chambers, and there cut their throats:
Once at Jerusalem, where the pilgrims kneeled,
I strewed powder on the marble stones,
And therewithal their knees would rankle, so
That I have laughed agood to see the cripples
Go limping home to Christendom on stilts.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Why this is something: make account of me
As of thy fellow; we are villains both:
Both circumcised, we hate Christians both:
Be true and secret, thou shalt want no gold.
But stand aside, here comes don Lodowick.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O Barabas well met; where is the diamond
You told me of?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I have it for you, sir; please you walk in with me:
What, ho, Abigal; open the door I say.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: In good time, father, here are letters come
From Ormus, and the post stays here within.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Give me the letters, daughter, do you hear?
Entertain Lodowick the governor's son
With all the courtesy you can afford;
Provided, that you keep your maidenhead.
Use him as if he were a Philistine. Aside.
Dissemble, swear, protest, vow to love him,
He is not of the seed of Abraham.
I am a little busy, sir, pray pardon me.
Abigal, bid him welcome for my sake.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: For your sake and his own he's welcome hither.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Daughter, a word more; kiss him, speak him fair,
And like a cunning Jew so cast about,
That ye be both made sure ere you come out.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: O father, don Mathias is my love.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I know it: yet I say make love to him;
Do, it is requisite it should be so.
Nay on my life it is my factor's hand,
But go you in, I'll think upon the account:
The account is made, for Lodowick dies.
My factor sends me word a merchant's fled
That owes me for a hundred tun of wine:
I weigh it thus much; I have wealth enough.
For now by this has he kissed Abigal;
And she vows love to him, and he to her.
As sure as heaven rained manna for the Jews,
So sure shall he and don Mathias die:
His father was my chiefest enemy.
Whither goes don Mathias? stay a while.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Whither but to my fair love Abigal?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Thou knowest, and heaven can witness it is true,
That I intend my daughter shall be thine.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Ay, Barabas, or else thou wrongest me much:

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: O heaven forbid I should have such a thought.
Pardon me though I weep; the governor's son
Will, whether I will or no, have Abigal:
He sends her letters, bracelets, jewels, rings.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Does she receive them?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: She? No, Mathias, no, but sends them back,
And when he comes, she locks herself up fast;
Yet through the key hole will he talk to her,
While she runs to the window looking out
When you should come and hale him from the door

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: O treacherous Lodowick!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Even now as I came home, he slipped me in,
And I am sure he is with Abigal.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: I'll rouse him thence.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Not for all Malta, therefore sheath your sword;
If you love me, no quarrels in my house;
But steal you in, and seem to see him not;
I'll give him such a warning e'er he goes
As he shall have small hopes of Abigal.
Away, for here they come,

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: What hand in hand, I cannot suffer this.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Mathias, as thou lovest me, not a word.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Well, let it pass, another time shall serve.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Barabas, is not that the widow's son?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ay, and take heed, for he hath sworn your death.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: My death? what is the base born peasant mad?

sp.speaker: B●r.
sp.l: No, no, but happily he stands in fear
Of that which you, I think, never dream upon,
My daughter here, a paltry silly girl.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why loves she don Mathias?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Doth she not with her smiling answer you?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: He has my heart, I smile against my will.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Barabas, thou knowest I have loved thy daughter long.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And so has she done you, even from a child.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: And now I can no longer hold my mind.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Nor I the affection that I bear to you

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: This is thy diamond, tell me, shall I have it?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Win it, and wear it, it is yet unsoiled,
O but I know your lordship would disdain
To marry with the daughter of a Jew:
And yet I'll give her many a golden cross
With Christian posies round about the ring.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: 'Tis not thy wealth, but her that I esteem,
Yet crave I thy consent.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And mine you have, yet let me talk to her;
This offspring of Cain, this Jebusite
That never tasted of the Passover,
Nor e'er shall see the land of Canaan,
nor our Messias that is yet to come,Aside.
This gentle maggot Lodowick I mean,
Must be deluded: let him have thy hand,
But keep thy heart till don Mathias comes.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: What shall I be betrothed to Lodowick?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: It's no sin to deceive a christian;
For they themselves hold it a principle,
Faith is not to be held with heretics;
But all are heretics that are not Jews;
This follows well, and therefore daughter fear not.
I have entreated her, and she will grant.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Then gentle Abigal plight thy faith to me.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: I cannot choose, seeing my father bids:
Nothing but death shall part my love and me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Now have I that for which my soul hath longed.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: So have not I, but yet I hope I shall.Aside.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: O wretched Abigal, what hast thee done?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why on the sudden is your colour changed?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: I know not, but farewell, I must be gone.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Stay her, but let her not speak one word more.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Mute a the sudden; here's a sudden change.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: O muse not at it, 'tis the hebrews' guise,
That maidens new betrothed should weep a while:
Trouble her not, sweet Lodowick depart:
She is thy wife, and thou shalt be mine heir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O, is't the custom, than I am resolved:
But rather let the brightsome heavens be dim,
And nature's beauty choke with stifling clouds,
Than my fair Abigal should frown on me.
There comes the villain, now I'll be revenged.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Be quiet Lodowick, it is enough
That I have made thee sure to Abigal.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Well, let him go. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Well, but for me, as you went in at doors
You had been stabbed, but not a word on't now;
Here must no speeches pass, nor swords be drawn.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Suffer me, Barabas, but to follow him.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No; so shall I, if any hurt be done,
Be made an accessary of your deeds;
Revenge it on him when you meet him next.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: For this I'll have his heart.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Do so; lo here I give thee Abigal.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: What greater gift can poor Mathias have?
Shall Lodowick rob me of so fair a love?
My life is not so dear as Abigal.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: My heart misgives me, that to cross your love,
He's with your mother, therefore after him.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: What, is he gone unto my mother?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Nay, if you will, stay till she comes herself.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: I cannot stay; for if my mother come,
She'll die with grief. Exit.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: I cannot take my leave of him for tears:
Father, why have you thus incensed them both?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What's that to thee?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: I'll make 'em friends again.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You'll make 'em friends? are there not Jews
Enough in Malta.
But thou must dote upon a christian?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: I will have don Mathias, he is my love.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Yes, you shall have him: go put her in.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Ay, I'll put her in.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Now tell me, Ithimore, how likest thou this?

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Faith master, I think by this
You purchase both their lives; is it not so?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: True; and it shall be cunningly performed.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: O, master, that I might have a hand in this.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ay, so thou shalt, 'tis thou must do the deed:
Take this and bear it to Mathias straight,
And tell him that it comes from Lodowick.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: 'Tis poisoned, is it not?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No, no, and yet it might be done that way:
It is a challenge feigned from Lodowick.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Fear not, I'll so set his heart a fire, that he
shall verily think it comes from him.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I cannot choose but like thy readiness:
Yet be not rash, but do it cunningly.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: As I behave myself in this, employ me hereafter.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Away then. Exit.
So, now will I go in to Lodowick,
And like a cunning spirit feign some lie,
Till I have set 'em both at enmity. Exit.
Since this town was besieged, my gain grows cold
The time has been, that but for one bare night
A hundred ducats have been freely given:
But now against my will I must be chaste.
And yet I know my beauty doth not fail.
From Venice merchants, and from Padua,
Were wont to come rare witted gentlemen,
Scholars I mean, learned and liberal;
And now, save Pilia-borza, comes there none,
And he is very seldom from my house;
And here he comes.

sp.speaker: Pilia.
sp.l: Hold thee, wench, there's something for thee to spend.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: 'Tis silver, I disdain it.

sp.speaker: Pilia.
sp.l: Ay, but the Jew has gold,
And I will have it or it shall go hard.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Tell me, how cam'st thou by this?

sp.speaker: Pilia.
sp.l: Faith, walking the back lanes through the gardens
I chanced to cast mine eye up to the Jews countinghouse
Where I saw some bags of money, and in the night I
Clambered up with my hooks, and as I was taking
My choice, I heard a rumbling in the house; so I took
only this, and run my way: but here's the Jews man.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Hide the bag.

sp.speaker: Pilia.
sp.l: Look not towards him, let's away:
'Zounds what a looking thou keepest,
Thou'lt betray's anon.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: O the sweetest face that ever I beheld! I know she is
A courtesan by her attire: now would I give a hundred
Of the Jews crowns that I had such a concubine.
Well, I have delivered the challenge in such sort,
As meet they will, and fighting die; brave sport.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: This is the place, now Abigal shall see
Whether Mathias holds her dear or no.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: What, dares the villain write in such base terms?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I did it, and revenge it if thou dar'st.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: O bravely fought, and yet they thrust not home.
Now Lodowick, now Mathias, so;
So now they have showed themselves to be tall fellows.
Within,part 'em, part 'em.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ay, part 'em now they are dead: farewell, farewell.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: What sight is this? my Lodowick slain!
These arms of mine shall be thy sepulchre.

sp.speaker: Mater,
sp.l: Who is this? my son Mathias slain!

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: O Lodowick! hadst thou perished by the Turk,
Wretched Ferneze might have venged thy death.

sp.speaker: Mater.
sp.l: Thy son slew mine, and I'll revenge his death.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Look, Katherin, look, thy son gave mine these wounds

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O leave to grieve me, I am grieved enough.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: O that my sighs could turn to lively breath;
And these my tears to blood, that he might live.

sp.speaker: Mater.
sp.l: Who made them enemies?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: I know not, and that grieves me most of all.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: My son loved thine.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: And so did Lodowick him.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Lend me that weapon that did kill my son,
And it shall murder me.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Nay madem stay, that weapon was my son's,
And on that rather should Ferneze die.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Hold, let's inquire the causers of their deaths,
That we may venge their blood upon their heads.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Then take them up, and let them be interred
Within one sacred monument of stone;
Upon which altar I will offer up
My daily sacrifice of sighs and tears,
And with my prayers pierce impartial heavens,
Till they the causers of our smarts,
Which forced their hands divide united hearts:
Come, Katherina, our losses equal are,
Then of true grief let us take equal share.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Why was there ever seen such villainy, so neatly
Plotted, and so well performed? both held in hand, and
Flatly both beguiled.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Why how now Ithimore, why laughest thou so?

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: O, mistress, ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Why what ailest thou?

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: O my master.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: O mistress! I have the bravest, gravest, secret, subtle
Bottle-nosed knave to my master, that ever gentleman had

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Say, knave, why railest upon my father thus?

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: O, my master has the bravest policy.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Wherein?

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Why, know you not?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Why no.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Know you not of Mathia and don Lodowick disaster?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: No, what was it?

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Why the devil invented a challenge, my Mr. writ it,
And I carried it, first to Lodowick, and imprimis to Mathia.
And then they met, as the story says,
In doleful wise they ended both their days.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: And was my father furtherer of their deaths?

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Am I Ithimore?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: So sure did your father write, and I carry the challenge.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Well, Ithimore, let me request thee this,
Go to the new made nunnery, and inquire
For any of the friars of st. Jaynes',
And say, I pray them come and speak with me.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: I pray, mistress, will you answer me to one question?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Well, sirrah, what is't?

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: A very feeling one; have not the nun's fine sport
With the friars now and then?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Go to, sirrah sauce, is this your question? get ye gone

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: I will forsooth, mistress.Exit

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Hard-hearted father, unkind Barabas,
Was this the pursuit of thy policy?
To make me show them favour severally,
That by my favour they should both be slain?
Admit thou lov'dst not Lodowick for his sin,
Yet don Mathias never offended thee:
But thou wert set upon extreme revenge,
Because the prior dispossessed thee once,
And couldst not venge it, but upon his son,
Nor on his son, but by Mathias means;
Nor on Mathias, but by murdering me.
But I perceive there is no love on earth,
Pity in Jews, nor piety in Turks.
But here comes cursed Ithimore with the friar.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: Virgo, salve.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: When duck you?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Welcome grave friar Ithimore: begone,Exit
Know, holy sir, I am bold to solicit thee.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: Wherein?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: To get me be admitted for a nun.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: Why Abigal it is not yet long since
That I did labour thy admission,
And than thou didst not like that holy life.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Then were my thoughts so frail and unconfirmed,
And I was chained to follies of the world:
But now experience, purchased with grief,
Has made me see the difference of things.
My sinful soul, alas, hath paced too long
The fatal labyrinth of misbelief,
Far from the son that gives eternal life.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: Who taught thee this?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: The abbess of the house,
Whose zealous admonition I embrace:
O therefore, Jacomi, let me be one,
Although unworthy of that sisterhood.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: Abigal I will, but see, thou change no more,
For that will be most heavy to thy soul.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: That was my father's fault.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: Thy father's, how?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Nay, you shall pardon me: o Barabas,
Though thou deservest hardly at my hands,
Yet never shall these lips bewray thy life.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: Come, shall we go?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: My duty waits on you. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What, Abigal become a nun again?
False, and unkind; what hast thou lost thy father?
And all unknown, and unconstrained of me,
Art thou again got to the nunnery?
Now here she writes, and wills me to repent.
Repentance? Spurca: what pretendeth this?
I fear she knows ('tis so) of my device
In don Mathias and Lodovico's deaths:
If so, 'tis time that it be seen into:
for she that varies from me in belief
Gives great presumption that she loves me not;
Or loving, doth dislike of something done:
But who comes here? O Ithimore come near;
Come near my love, come near thy master's life,
My trusty servant, nay, my second life;
For I have now no hope but even in thee;
And on that hope my happiness is built:
When sawest thou Abigal?

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Today.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: With whom?

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: A friar.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: A friar? false villain, he hath done the deed.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: How, sir?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Why made mine Abigal a nun.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: That's no lie, for she sent me for him.

sp.speaker: Brr.
sp.l: O unhappy day,
False, credulous, inconstant Abigal!
But let 'em go: and Ithimore, from hence
Never shall she grieve me more with her disgrace;
Never shall she live to inherit ought of mine,
Be blessed of me, nor come within my gates,
But perish underneath my bitter curse
Like Cain by Adam, for his brother's death.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: O master.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ithimore, entreat not for her, I am moved,
And she is hateful to my soul and me:
And lest thou yield to this that I entreat,
I cannot think but that thou hatest my life.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Who I, master? Why I'll run to some rock and
Throw myself headlong into the sea; why I'll do any
Thing for your sweet sake.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: O trusty Ithimore; no servant, but my friend;
I here adopt thee for mine only heir,
All that I have is thine when I am dead,
And whilst I live use help; spend as myself;
Here take my keys, I'll give 'em thee anon:
go buy thee garments: but thou shalt not want:
Only know this, that thus thou art to do:
But first go fetch me in the pot of rice
That for our supper stands upon the fire.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: I hold my head my master's hungry: I go sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Thus every villain ambles after wealth
Although he never be richer than in hope:
But hush't.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Here 'tis, master.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Well said, Ithimore; what hast thou brought
The ladle with thee too?

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Yes, sir, the proverb says, he that eats with the devil
Had need of a long spoon, I have brought you a ladle.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Very well, Ithimore, then now be secret,
And for thy sake, whom I so dear love,
Now shalt thou see the death of Abigal,
That thou mayst freely live to be my heir.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Why, master, will you poison her with a mess of rice
Porridge that will preserve life, make her round and plump,
And batten more than you are aware.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I but Ithimore seest thou this?
It is a precious powder that I bought
Of an Italian in Anoona once,
Whose operation is to bind, infect,
And poison deeply: yet not appear
In forty hours after it is ta'en.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: How master?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Thus Ithimore:
This even they use in Malta here ('tis called
Saint Jaques' even) and then I say they use
To send their alms unto the nunneries:
Among the rest bear this, and set it there;
There's a dark entry where they take it in,
Where they must neither see the messenger,
Nor make enquiry who hath sent it them.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: How so?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Belike there is some ceremony in't.
There Ithimore must thou go place this plot:
Stay, let me spice it first.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Pray do, and let me help you Mr. pray let me taste first.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Prithee do: what sayest thou now?

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Troth Mr. I'm loath such a pot of pottage should be spoilt.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Peace, Ithimore, 'tis better so then spared.
Assure thyself thou shalt have broth by the eye.
My purse, my coffer, and myself is thine.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Well, master, I go.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Stay, first let me stir it Ithimore.
As fatal be it to her as the draught
Of which great Alexander drunk, and died:
And with her let it work like Borgias wine,
Whereof his sire, the Pope, was poisoned.
In few, the blood of Hydra, Lerna's bane;
The joince of Hebon, and cocytus breath,
And all the poisons of the Stygian pool
Break from the fiery kingdom; and in this
Vomit your venom, and envenom her
That like a fiend hath left her father thus.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: What a blessing has he given't? was ever pot of
Rice porridge so sauced? what shall I do with it?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: O my sweet Ithimore go set it down
And come again so soon as thou hast done,
For I have other business for thee.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Here's a drench to poison a whole stable of
Flanders mares: I'll carry't to the nuns with a powder.

sp.speaker: B●r.
sp.l: And the horse pestilence to boot; away.

sp.speaker: Ith,
sp.l: I am gone.
Pay me my wages for my work is done. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I'll pay thee with a vengeance Ithimore. Exit.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Welcome great bashaws, how fares Calymath,
What wind drives you thus into Malta rhode?

sp.speaker: Bash.
sp.l: The wind that bloweth all the world besides,
Desire of gold.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Desire of gold, great sir?
That's to be gotten in the western Ind:
In Malta are no golden minerals.

sp.speaker: Bash.
sp.l: To you of Malta thus saith Calymath:
The time you took for respite, is at hand,
For the performance of your promise past;
And for the tribute-money I am sent.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Bashaw, in brief, shalt have no tribute here,
Nor shall the heathens live upon our spoil:
First will we raze the city walls ourselves,
Lay waste the island, hew the temples down,
And shipping of our goods to Sicily,
Open an entrance for the wasteful sea,
Whose billows beating the resistless banks,
Shall overflow it with their refluence.

sp.speaker: Bash.
sp.l: Well, governor, since thou hast broke the league
By that denial of the promised tribute,
Talk not of racing down your city walls,
You shall not need trouble yourselves so far,
For Selim-calymath shall come himself,
And with brass-bullets batter down your towers,
And turn proud Malta to a wilderness
For these intolerable wrongs of yours; and so farewell.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Farewell:
And now you men of Malta look about,
And let's provide to welcome Calymath:
Close your portcullis, charge your basilisks,
And as you profitably take up arms,
So now courageously encounter them;
For by this answer, broken is the league,
And naught is to be looked for now but wars,
And naught to us more welcome is then wars.Exeunt

sp.speaker: 1 Fry.
sp.l: O brother, brother, all the nuns are sick,
And physic will not help them, they must die.

sp.speaker: 2 Fry.
sp.l: The abbess sent for me to be confessed:
O what a sad confession will there be?

sp.speaker: 1 Fry.
sp.l: And so did fair Maria send for me:
I'll to her lodging; hereabouts she lies. Exit.

sp.speaker: 2 Fry.
sp.l: What, all dead save only Abigall?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: And I shall die too, for I feel death coming.
Where is the friar that conversed with me?

sp.speaker: 2 Fry.
sp.l: O he is gone to see the other nuns.

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: I sent for him, but seeing you are come
Be you my ghostly father; and first know,
That in this house I lived religiously,
Chaste, and devout, much sorrowing for my sins,
But ere I came —

sp.speaker: 2 Fry.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: I did offend high heaven so grievously,
As I am almost desperate for my sins:
And one offence torments me more than all.
You knew Mathias and don Lodowick?

sp.speaker: 2 Fry.
sp.l: Yes, what of them?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: My father did contract me to 'em both:
First to don Lodowick, him I never loved;
Mathias was the man that I held dear,
And for his sake did I become a nun.

sp.speaker: 2 Fry.
sp.l: So, say how was their end?

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: Both jealous of my love, envied each other:
And by my father's practice, which is there
Set down at large, the gallants were both slain.

sp.speaker: 2 Fry.
sp.l: O monstrous villainy:

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: To work my peace, this I confess to thee:
Reveal it not, for then my father dies.

sp.speaker: 2 Fry.
sp.l: Know that confession must not be revealed,
The canon law forbids it, and the priest
That makes it known, being degraded first,
Shall be condemned, and then sent to the fire,

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.l: So I have heard; pray therefore keep it close,
Death seizeth on my heart, ah gentle friar
convert my father that he may be saved,
And witness that I die a christian.

sp.speaker: 2 Fry.
sp.l: Ay, and a virgin too, that grieves me most:
But I must to the Jew and exclaim on him,
And make him stand in fear of me.

sp.speaker: 1 Fry.
sp.l: O brother, all the nuns are dead, let's bury them.

sp.speaker: 2 Fry.
sp.l: First help to bury this, then go with me
And help me to exclaim against the Jew.

sp.speaker: 1 Fry.
sp.l: Why? what has he done?

sp.speaker: 2 Fry.
sp.l: A thing that makes me tremble to unfold.

sp.speaker: 1 Fry.
sp.l: What has he crucified a child?

sp.speaker: 2 Fry.
sp.l: No, but a worse thing: 'twas told me in shrift,
Thou knowest 'tis death and if it be revealed.
Come let's away. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus quartus.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: There is no music to a Christian's knell:
How sweet the bells ring now the nuns are dead
That sound at other times like tinkers pans?
I was afraid the poison had not wrought;
Or though it wrought, it would have done no good,
For every year they swell, and yet they live;
Now all are dead, not one remains alive.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: That's brave Mr. but think you it will not be known

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: How can it if we two be secret.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: For my part fear you not.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I'd cut thy throat if I did.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: And reason too; but here's a royal monastery hard
By, good master let me poison all the monks.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Thou shalt not need, for now the nuns are dead,
they'll die with grief.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Do you not sorrow for your daughter's death?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No, but I grieve because she lived so long an hebrew Catho diabola.
Born, and would become a christian.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Look, look, Mr. here come two religious caterpillars.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I smelled 'em ere they came.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: God-a-mercy nose; come let's begone.

sp.speaker: 2 Fry.
sp.l: Stay wicked Jew, repent, I say, and stay.

sp.speaker: 1 Fry.
sp.l: Thou hast offended, therefore must be damned.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I fear they know we sent the poisoned broth.

sp.speaker: Ith,
sp.l: And so do I, master, therefore speak 'em fair.
Barabas, thou hast —
Ay, that thou hast —

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: True, I have money, what though I have?
Thou art a —
Ay, that thou art a —

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What needs all this? I know I am a Jew.
Thy daughter —
Ay, thy daughter, —

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: O speak not of her, than I die with grief.
Remember that —
Ay, remember that —

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I must needs say that I have been a great usurer.
Thou hast committed —

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Fornication? but that was in another country:
And besides, the wench is dead.
Ay, but Barabas remember Mathias and don Lodowick.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Why, what of them?
I will not say that by a forged challenge they met.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: She has confessed, and we are both undone;
My bosom inmates, but I must dissemble. Aside.
O holy friars, the burden of my sins
Lie heavy on my soul; then pray you tell me,
Is't not too late now to turn christian?
I have been zealous in the Jewish faith,
Hard hearted to the poor, a covetous wretch,
that would for lucre's sake have sold my soul.
A hundred for a hundred I have ta'en;
And now for store of wealth may I compare
With all the Jews in Malta; but what is wealth?
I am a Jew, and therefore am I lost.
Would penance serve for this my sin,
I could afford to whip myself to death.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: And so could I; but penance will not serve.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: To fast, to pray, and wear a shirt of hair,
And on my knees creep to Jerusalem,
Cellars of wine, and sollers full of wheat,
Warehouses stuffed with spices and with drugs,
Whole chests of gold, in bullion, and in coin,
Besides I know not how much weight in pearl
Orient and round, have I within my house;
At Alexandria, merchandise unsold:
But yesterday two ships went from this town,
Their voyage will be worth ten thousand crowns.
In Florence, Venice, Antwerp, London, civil,
Frankford, Lubeck, Mosco, and where not,
Have I debts owing; and in most of these,
Great sums of money lying in the bancho;
All this I'll give to some religious house
So I may be baptised and live therein.
O good Barabas come to our house.
O no, good Barabas come to our house.
And Barabas, you know —

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I know that I have highly sinned,
You shall convert me, you shall have all my wealth.
O Barabas, their laws are strict.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I know they are, and I will be with you.
They wear no shirts, and they go barefoot too.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Then 'tis not for me; and I am resolved
You shall confess me, and have all my goods.
Good Barabas come to me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You see I answer him, and yet he stays;
Rid him away, and go you home with me.
I'll be with you tonight .

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Come to my house at one o'clock this night.
You hear your answer, and you may be gone.
Why go get you away.
I will not go for thee.
Not, then I'll make thee go.
How, dost call me rogue? Fight.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Part 'em, master, part 'em.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: This is mere frailty, brothers, be content.
Friar Barnardine go you with Ithimore.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: You know my mind, let me alone with him;
Why does he go to thy house, let him begone.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I'll give him something and so stop his mouth.
I never heard of any man but he
Maligned the order of the Iacobines:
But do you think that I believe his words?
Why brother you converted Abigall;
And I am bound in charity to requite it,
