And so I will, o Jocome, fail not but come.

sp.speaker: Fry,
sp.l: But Barabas who shall be your godfathers,
For presently you shall be shrived.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Marry the Turk shall be one of my godfathers,
But not a word to any of your convent.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: I warrant thee, Barabas. Exit

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: So now the fear is past, and I am safe:
For he that shrived her is within my house,
What if I murdered him ere Jocoma comes?
Now I have such a plot for both their lives,
As never Jew nor Christian knew the like:
One turned my daughter, therefore he shall die;
The other knows enough to have my life,
Therefore 'tis not requisite he should live.
But are not both these wise men to suppose
That I will leave my house, my goods, and all,
To fast and be well whipped; I'll none of that.
Now friar Bernardine I come to you,
I'll feast you, lodge you, give you fair words,
And after that, I and my trusty Turk —
No more but so: it must and shall be done.
Ithimore, tell me, is the friar asleep?

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Yes; and I know not what the reason is.
Do what I can he will not strip himself,
Nor go to bed, but sleeps in his own clothes
I fear me he mistrusts what we intend.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No, 'tis an order which the friar's use:
Yet if he knew our meanings, could he scape?

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: No, none can hear him, cry he never so loud.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Why true, therefore did I place him there:
The other chambers open towards the street.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: You loiter, master, wherefore stay we thus?
O how I long to see him shake his heels.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Come on, sirrah, off with your girdle, make a handsome noose;
Friar awake.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: What do you mean to strangle me?

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Yes, 'cause you use to confess.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Blame not us but the proverb, confess and be hanged
Pull hard.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: What, will you save my life?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Pull hard, I say, you would have had my goods.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Ay, and our lives too therefore pull amain.
'Tis neatly done, sir, here's no print at all.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Then is it as it should be, take him up.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Nay, Mr. be ruled by me a little; so, let him lean
Upon his staff; excellent, he stands as if he were begging of bacon.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Who would not think but that this friar lived?
What time a night is't now, sweet Ithimore?

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Towards one.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Then will not Jocoma be long from hence.

sp.speaker: Joco.
sp.l: This is the hour wherein I shall proceed;
O happy hour, wherein I shall convert
an infidel, and bring his gold into our treasury.
But soft, is not this Bernardine? it is;
And understanding I should come this way,
Stands here a purpose, meaning me some wrong,
And intercept my going to the Jew; Bernardine;
Wilt thou not speak? thou think'st I see thee not;
Aways I'd wish thee, and let me go by:
No, wilt thou not? nay then I'll force my way;
And see● staff stands ready for the purpose:
As thou likest that, stop me another time.

div.stage: Strike him, he falls. Enter Barabas.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Why how now Jocoma, what hast thou done?

sp.speaker: Ioco.
sp.l: Why stricken him that would have stroke at me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Who is it Bernardine? now out alas, he is slain.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Ay, Mr. he's slain; look how his brains drop out on's nose.

sp.speaker: Joco.
sp.l: Good sirs I have don't, but nobody knows it but
You two, I may escape.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: So might my man and I hang with you for company.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: No, let us bear him to the magistrates.

sp.speaker: Joco.
sp.l: Good Barabas let me go.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No, pardon me, the law must have his course.
I must be forced to give in evidence,
That being importuned by this Bernardine
To be a christian, I shut him out,
And there he sat: now I to keep my word,
And give my goods and substance to your house,
Was up thus early; with intent to go
Unto your friary, because you stayed.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Fie upon 'em, Mr. will you turn christian, when
Holy friars turn devils and murder one another.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No, for this example I'll remain a Jew:
Heaven bless me; what, a friar a murderer?
When shall you see a Jew commit the like?

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Why a Turk could ha' done no more.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Tomorrow is the sessions; you shall to it.
Come Ithimore, let's help to take him hence.

sp.speaker: Joco.
sp.l: Villains, I am a sacred person, touch me not.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: The law shall touch you, we'll but lead you, we.
Alas I could weep at your calamity.
Take in the staff too, for that must be shown:
Law wills that each particular be known. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Pilia-borza, didst thou meet with Ithimore?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: I did.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: And didst thou deliver my letter?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: I did.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: And what think'st thou, will he come?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: I think so, and yet I cannot tell, for at the reading of
The letter, he looked like a man of another world.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Why so?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: That such a base slave as he should be saluted by such
A tall man as I am, from such a beautiful dame as you.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: And what said he?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Not a wise word, only gave me a nod, as who should say, is it even so; and so I left him, being driven to a nonplus at the critical aspect of my terrible countenance.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: Upon mine own freehold within 40 foot of the gallows, cunning his neck-verse I take it, looking of a friar's execution, whom I saluted with an old hempen proverb, hidie tibi, cras mihi, and so I left him to the mercy of the hangman: but the exercise being done, see where he comes.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.p: I never knew a man take his death so patiently as this friar; he was ready to leap off e'er the halter was about his neck; and when the hangman had put on his hempen tippet, he made such haste to his prayers, as if he had had another cure to serve; well, go whither he will, I'll be none of his followers in haste:
sp.l: And now I think on't, going to the execution, a fellow
Met me with a mustache's like a raven's wing, and
A dagger with a hilt like a warming-pan, and he
gave me a letter from one madam Bellamira,
Saluting me in such sort as if he had meant to make
Clean my boots with his lips; the effect was, that
I should come to her house, I wonder what the reason is;
It may be she sees more in me than I can find in
Myself: for she writes further, that she loves me
Ever since she saw me, and who would not requite such
Love● here's her house, and here she comes, and now
Would I were gone, I am not worthy to look upon her.

sp.speaker: Pilia.
sp.l: This is the gentleman you writ to.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Gentleman, he flouts me, what gentry can be in a
Poor Turk of ten pence? I'll be gone.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Is't not a sweet faced youth, Pilia?

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Again, sweet youth; did not you, sir, bring the sweet
Youth a letter?

sp.speaker: Pilia.
sp.l: I did sir, and from this gentlewoman, who as my
Self, and the rest of the family, stand or fall at your service.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Though woman's modesty should hale me back,
I can withhold no longer; welcome sweet love.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Now am I clean, or rather foully out of the way.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Whither so soon?

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: I'll go steal some money from my master to
Make me handsome:
Pray pardon me, I must go see a ship discharged.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Canst thou be so unkind to leave me thus?

sp.speaker: Pilia.
sp.l: And ye did but know how she loves you, sir.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Nay, I care not how much she loves me;
Sweet Allamira, would I had my master's wealth for thy sake:

sp.speaker: Pilia.
sp.l: And you can have it, sir, and if you please.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: If 'twere above ground I could, and would have it;
But he hides and buries it up as partridges do
Their eggs, under the earth.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: And is't not possible to find it out?

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: By no means possible.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: What shall we do with this base villain then?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Let me alone, do but you speak him fair:
but you know some secrets of the Jew, which if they were
Revealed, would do him harm.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Ay, and such as — go to, no more,
I'll make him send me half he has, and glad he scapes so too.
Pen and ink:
I'll write unto him, we'll have money straight.

sp.speaker: Pil,
sp.l: Send for a hundred crowns at least.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Ten hundred thousand crowns, — Mr. Barabas.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Write not so submissively, but threatening him.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Sirrah Barabas, send me a hundred crowns.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Put in two hundred at least.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: I charge thee send me 300 by this bearer, and this
Shall be your warrant; if you do not, no more but so.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Tell him you will confess.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Otherwise I'll confess all, vanish and return in a twinkle.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Let me alone, I'll use him in his kind.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Hang him Jew.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Now, gentle Ithimore, lie in my lap.
Where are my maids? provide a running banquet;
Send to the merchant, bid him bring me silks,
Shall Ithimore my love go in such rags?

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: And bid the jeweller come hither too.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: I have no husband, sweet, I'll marry thee.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Content, but we will leave this paltry land,
And sail from hence to Greece, to lovely Greece,
I'll be thy Jason, thou my golden fleece;
Where painted carpets o'er the meads are hurled,
And Bacchus' vineyards o'erspread the world:
Where woods and forests go in goodly green,
I'll be Adonis, thou shalt be love's Queen.
The meads, the orchards, and the primrose lanes,
Instead of sedge and reed, bear sugar canes:
Thou in those groves, by dis above,
Shalt live with me and be my love.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Whither will I not go with gentle Ithimore?

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: How now? hast thou the gold?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: It●.
sp.l: But came it freely, did the cow give down her milk freely?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: At reading of the letter, he stared and stamped, and turned
Aside, I took him by the sterd, and looked upon him thus;
Told him he were best to send it, than he huged and embraced me.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Rather for fear then love.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Then like a Jew he laughed and jeered, and told me he
Loved me for your sake, and said what a faithful servant you had been.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: The more villain he to keep me thus:
Here's goodly ''parel, is there not?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: To conclude, he gave me ten crowns.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: But ten? I'll not leave him worth a grey groat, give
Me a ream of paper, we'll have a kingdom of gold for't.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Write for 500 crowns.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Sirrah Jew, as you love your life send me 500 crowns,
And give the bearer 100. Tell him I must have't.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: I warrant your worship shall have't.

sp.speaker: Ith,
sp.l: And if he ask why I demand so much, tell him,
I scorn to write a line under a hundred crowns.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: You'd make a rich poet, sir. I am gone. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Take thou the money, spend it for my sake.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: 'Tis not thy money, but thyself I weigh:
Thus Bellamira esteems of gold;
But thus of thee. —Kiss him.—

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: That kiss again; she runs division of my lips.
What an eye she casts on me?
It twinkles like a star.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Come my dear love, let's in and sleep together.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: O that ten thousand nights were put in one,
That we might sleep seven years together afore
We wake.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Come amorous wag, first banquet and then sleep.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Barabas send me 300 crowns.
Plain Barabas: o that wicked courtesan!
He was not wont to call me Barabas.
Or else I will confess: ay, there it goes:
But if I get him coupe de gorge, for that
He sent a shaggy tottered staring slave,
That when he speaks, draws out his grisly beard,
And winds it twice or thrice about his ear;
Whose face has been a grindstone for men's swords,
His hands are hacked, some fingers cut quite off;
Who when he speaks, grunts like a hog, and looks
Like one that is employed in catzerie,
And crossbiting such a rogue
As is the husband to a hundred whores:
And I by him must send three hundred crowns.
Well, my hope is, he will not stay there still;
And when he comes: o that he were but here!

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Jew, I must ha' more gold.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Why wantest thou any of thy tale?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: No; but 300 will not serve his turn.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Not serve his turn, sir?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: No sir; and therefore I must have 500 more.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I'll rather —

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: O good words, sir, and send it you were best, see,
There's his letter.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Might he not as well come as send; pray bid him
Come and fetch it, what he writes for you, ye shall have straight.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Ay, and the rest too, or else —

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I must make this villain away: please you dine
With me, sir, and you shall be most heartily poisoned.Aside

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: No god-a-mercy, shall I have these crowns?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I cannot do it, I have lost my keys.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: O, if that be all, I can pick open your locks.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Or climb up to my countinghouse window:
You know my meaning.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: I know enough, and therefore talk not to me of your
Countinghouse, the gold, or know Jew it is in my power to hang thee.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I am betrayed.
'tis not 500 crowns that I esteem,
I am not moved at that: this angers me,
That he who knows I love him as myself
Should write in this imperious vain? why sir,
You know I have no child, and unto whom
Should I leave all but unto Ithimore?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Here's many words but no crowns; the crowns.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Commend me to him, sir, most humbly,
And unto your good mistress as unknown.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Speak, shall I have 'em, sir?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Sir here they are.
O that I should part with so much gold!
Here take 'em, fellow, with as good a will —
— as I and see thee hanged; o, love stops my breath:
Never loved man servant as I do Ithimore.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: I know it, sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Pray when, sir, shall I see you at my house?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Soon enough to your cost, sir:
Fare you well. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Nay to thine own cost, villain, if thou comest.
Was ever Jew tormented as I am?
To have a shagrag knave to come
300 crowns, and then 500 crowns?
Well, I must seek a means to rid 'em all,
And presently: for in his villainy
He will tell all he knows and I shall die for't. I have it.
I will in some disguise go see the slave,
And how the villain revels with my gold. Exit.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: I'll pledge thee, love, and therefore drink it off.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Sayest thou me so? have at it; and do you hear?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Go to, it shall be so.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Of that condition I will drink it up; here's to thee.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Nay, I'll have all or none.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: There, if thou lovest me do not leave a drop.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Love thee, fill me three glasses.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Three and fifty dozen, I'll pledge thee,

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Knavily spoke, and like a knight at arms.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Hey Rivo castiliano, a man's a man.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Now to the Jew.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Ha to the Jew, and send me money you were best.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: What wouldst thou do if he should send thee none?

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Do nothing; but I know what I know,
He's a murderer.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: I had not thought he had been so brave a man.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: You knew Mathias and the governor's son, he and
I killed 'em both, and yet never touched 'em.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: O bravely done.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: I carried the broth that poisoned the nuns, and he
And I snickle hand too fast, strangled a friar.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: You two alone.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: We two, and 'twas never known, nor never shall
Be for me.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: This shall with me unto the governor.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: And fit it should: but first let's ha' more gold
Come gentle Ithimore, lie in my lap.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Love me little, love me long, let music rumble,
Whilst I in thy incony lap do tumble.

div.stage: Enter Barabas with a lute, disguised.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: A French musician, come let's hear your skill?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Must tuna my lute for sound, twang twang first.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Wilt drink Frenchman, here's to thee with a —
Pox on this drunken hiccup.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Gramercy monsieur.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Prithee, Pilia-borza, bid the fiddler give me
The posy in his hat there.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Sirrah, you must give my mistress your posy.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: A voustre commandement madam.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: How sweet, my Ithimore, the flowers smell.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Like thy breath, sweetheart, no violet like 'em.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Foh, methinks they stink like a hollyhock.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: So, now I am revenged upon 'em all.
The scent thereof was death, I poisoned it.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Play, fiddler, or I'll cut your cat's guts into chitterlings
pardona moy, be no in tune yet; so now, now all be in.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Give him a crown, and fill me out more wine.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: There's two crowns for thee, play.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: How liberally the villain gives me mine own gold.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Methinks he fingers very well.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: So did you when you stole my gold.Aside

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: How swift he runs.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You run swifter when yond threw my gold out of
My window.Aside.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Musician, hast been in Malta long?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Two, three, four month madam.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Dost not know a Jew, one Barabas?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Very much, monsieur, you no be his man.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: His man?

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: I scorn the peasant, tell him so.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: He knows it already.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: 'Tis a strange thing of that Jew, he lives upon
Pickled grasshoppers, and sauced mushrooms.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What a slave's this?
The governor feeds not as I do.Aside.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: He never put on clean shirt since he was circumcised

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: O rascal! I change myself twice a day. Aside

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: The hat he wears, Judas left under the elder
When he hanged himself.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: 'Twas sent me for a present from the great cham.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: A masty slave he is;
Whether now, fiddler?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Pardona moy, monsieur, we be no well. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Farewell Fidler: one letter more to the Jew.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Prithee sweet love, one more, and write it sharp.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: No, I'll send by word of mouth now;
Bid him deliver thee a thousand crowns, by the same
Token, that the nuns loved rice, that friar Bernardine
Slept in his own clothes,
Any of 'em will do it.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Let me alone to urge it now I know the meaning.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: The meaning has a meaning; come let's in:
To undo a Jew is charity, and not sin .

div.head: Actus quintus.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Now, gentlemen, betake you to your arms,
And see that Malta be well fortified;
And it behoves you to be resolute;
For Calymath having hovered here so long,
Will win the town, or die before the walls.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.l: And die he shall, for we will never yield.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: O bring us to the governor.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Away with her, she is a courtesan.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Whate'er I am, yet governor hear me speak;
I bring thee news by whom thy son was slain:
Mathias did it not, it was the Jew.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Who, besides the slaughter of these gentlemen,
Poisoned his own daughter and the nuns,
Strangled a friar, and I know not what
Mischief beside.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Had we but proof of this.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Strong proof, my lord, his man's now at my
Lodging that was his agent, he'll confess it all.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Go fetch him straight, I always feared that Jew.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I'll go alone, dogs do not hale me thus.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Nor me neither, I cannot outrun you constable, o my belly.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: One dram of powder more had made all sure,
What a damned slave was I?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Make fires, heat irons, let the rack be fetched.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.l: Nay stay, my lord, 'tmay be he will confess.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Confess; what mean you, lords, who should confess?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Thou and thy Turk; 'twas you that slew my son.

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: Guilty, my lord, I confess; your son and Mathias
Were both contracted unto Abigall,
Forged a counterfeit challenge.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: Who carried that challenge?

sp.speaker: Ith.
sp.l: I carried it, I confess, but who writ it?
Marry even he that strangled Bernardine, poisoned the
Nuns, and his own daughter.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Away with him, his sight is death to me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: For what, you men of Malta, hear me speak;
She is a courtesan and he a thief,
And he my bondman, let me have law,
For none of this can prejudice my life:

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Once more away with him; you shall have law.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Devils do your worst, I live in spite of you.
As these have spoke so be it to their souls:
I hope the poisoned flowers will work anon. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mater.
sp.l: Was my Mathias murdered by the Jew?
Ferneze, 'twas thy son that murdered him.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Be patient, gentle madam, it was he,
He forged the daring challenge made them fight.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Where is the Jew, where is that murderer?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: In prison till the law has passed on him.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: My lord, the courtesan and her man are dead;
So is the Turk, and Barabas the Jew.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Dead?

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Dead, my lord, and here they bring his body.

sp.speaker: Bosco.
sp.l: This sudden death of his is very strange.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Wonder not at it, sir, the heavens are just:
Their deaths were like their lives, then think not of 'em
Since they are dead, let them be buried.
For the Jews body, throw that o'er the walls,
To be a prey for vultures and wild beasts.
So, now away and fortify the town. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What, all alone? well fare sleepy drink.
I'll be revenged on this accursed town;
For by my means Calymath shall enter in.
I'll help to slay their children and their wives,
To fire the churches, pull their houses down,
Take my goods too, and seize upon my lands:
I hope to see the governor a slave,
And, rowing in a galley, whipped to death.

sp.speaker: Caly.
sp.l: Whom have we there, a spy?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Yes, my good lord, one that can spy a place
Where you may enter, and surprise the town:
My name is Barabas; I am a Jew.

sp.speaker: Caly.
sp.l: Art thou that Jew whose goods we heard were sold
For tribute-money?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: The very same, my lord:
And since that time they have hired a slave my man
To accuse me of a thousand villainies:
I was imprisoned, but scaped their hands.

sp.speaker: Caly.
sp.l: Didst break prison?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No, no:
I drank of poppy and cold mandrake juice;
And being asleep, belike they thought me dead,
And threw me o'er the walls so, or how else,
The Jew is here, and rests at your command.

sp.speaker: Caly.
sp.l: 'Twas bravely done: but tell me, Barabas,
Canst thou, as thou reportest, make Malta ours?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Fear not, my lord, for here against the truce,
The rock is hollow, and of purpose digged,
To make a passage for the running streams
And common channels of the city.
Now whilst you give assault unto the walls,
I'll lead 500 soldiers through the vault,
And rise with them i'th middle of the town,
open the gates for you to enter in,
And by this means the city is your own.

sp.speaker: Caly.
sp.l: If this be true, I'll make thee governor.

sp.speaker: Jew.
sp.l: And if it be not true, then let me die.

sp.speaker: Caly.
sp.l: Thou'st doomed thyself, assault it presently.

div.stage: Alarms. Enter Turks, Barabas, governor, and knights prisoners.

sp.speaker: Caly.
sp.l: Now veil your pride you captive Christians,
And kneel for mercy to your conquering foe:
Now where's the hope you had of haughty Spain?
Ferneze, speak, had it not been much better
To kept thy promise then be thus surprised?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: What should I say, we are captives and must yield.

sp.speaker: Caly.
sp.l: Ay, villains, you must yield, and under Turkish yokes
Shall groaning bear the burden of our ire;
And Barabas, as erst we promised thee,
For thy desert we make the governor,
Use them at thy discretion.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Thanks, my lord.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: O fatal day to fall into the hands
Of such a traitor and unhallowed Jew!
What greater misery could heaven inflict?

sp.speaker: Caly.
sp.l: 'Tis our command: and Barabas, we give
To guard thy person, these our janissaries:
Entreat them well, as we have used thee.
And now, brave pashas, come, we'll walk about
The ruined town, and see the wrack we made:
Farewell brave Jew, farewell great Barabas. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: May all good fortune follow Calymath.
And now, as entrance to our safety,
To prison with the governor and these
Captains, his consorts and confederates.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: O villain, heaven will be revenged on thee.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: A way, no more, let him not trouble me.
Thus hast thou gotten, by thy policy,
no simple place, no small authority,
I now am governor of Malta; true,
But Malta hates me, and in hating me
My life's in danger, and what boots it thee
Poor Barabas, to be the governor,
Whenas thy life shall be at their command?
No, Barabas, this must be looked into;
And since by wrong thou gottest authority,
Maintain it bravely by firm policy,
At least unprofitably lose it not:
For he that liveth in authority,
And neither gets him friends, nor fills his bags,
Lives like the ass that Aesop speaketh of,
That labours with a load of bread and wine,
And leaves it off to snap on thistle tops:
But Barabas will be more circumspect.
Begin betimes, occasion's bald behind,
Slip not thine opportunity, for fear too late
Thou seekest for much, but canst not compass it
Within here.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: My lord?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ay, lord, thus slaves will learn.
Now governor stand by there, wait within,
This is the reason that I sent for thee;
Thou seest thy life, and Malta's happiness,
Are at my arbitrament; and Barabas
At his discretion may dispose of both:
Now tell me, governor, and plainly too,
What thinkst thou shall become of it and thee?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: This; Barabas, since things are in thy power,
I see no reason but of Malta's wrack,
Nor hope of thee but extreme cruelty,
Nor fear I death, nor will I flatter thee.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Governor, good words, be not so furious;
'Tis not thy life which can avail me ought,
Yet you do live, and live for me you shall:
and as for Malta's ruin, think you not
'Twere slender policy for Barabas
To dispossess himself of such a place?
For sith, as once you said, within this I'll
In Malta here, that I have got my goods,
And in this city still have had success,
And now at length am grown your governor,
Yourselves shall see it shall not be forgotten:
For as a friend not known, but in distress,
I'll rear up Malta now remediless.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Will Barabas recover Malta's loss?
Will Barabas be good to Christians?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What wilt thou give me, governor, to procure
A dissolution of the slavish bands
Wherein the Turk hath yoked your land and you?
What will you give me if I render you
The life of Calymath, surprise his men,
And in an out house of the city shut
His soldiers, till I have consumed 'em all with fire?
What will you give him that procureth this?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Do but bring this to pass which thou pretendest,
Deal truly with us as thou intimatest,
And I will send amongst the citizens
And by my letters privately procure
Great sums of money for thy recompense:
Nay more, do this, and live thou governor still.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Nay, do thou this, Ferneze, and be free;
Governor, I enlarge thee, live with me,
Go walk about the city, see thy friends:
Tush, send not letters to 'em, go thyself,
And let me see what money thou canst make;
Here is my hand that I'll set Malta free:
And thus we cast it: to a solemn feast
I will invite young Selim-calymath,
Where be thou present only to perform
One stratagem that I'll impart to thee,
Wherein no danger shall betide thy life,
and I will warrant Malta free for ever.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Here is my hand, believe me, Barabas,
I will be there, and do as thou desirest;
When is the time?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Governor, presently.
For Calymath, when he hath viewed the town,
Will take his leave and sail towards, Ottoman,

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Then will I, Barabas, about this coin,
And bring it with me to thee in the evening.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Do so, but fail not; now farewell Ferneze
And thus far roundly goes the business:
Thus loving neither, will I live with both,
Making a profit of my policy;
And he from whom my most advantage comes,
Shall be my friend.
This is the life we Jews are used to lead;
And reason too, for Christians do the like:
Well, now about effecting this device:
First to surprise great Selim's soldiers,
And then to make provision for the feast,
That at one instant all things may be done,
My policy detests prevention:
To what event my secret purpose drives,
I know; and they shall witness with their lives. Exit.

sp.speaker: Caly.
sp.l: Thus have we viewed the city, seen the sack,
And caused the ruins to be new repaired,
Which with our bombards shot and basilisk,
We rent in sunder at our entry:
And now I see the situation,
And how secure this conquered island stands
Environed with the Mediterranean sea,
Strong countermined with other petty isles;
And towards Calabria backed by Sicily,
Two lofty turrets that command the town.
When Syracusan Dionysius reigned;
I wonder how it could be conquered thus?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: From Barabas, Malta's governor, I bring
A message unto mighty Calymath;
Hearing his sovereign was bound for sea,
To sail to Turkey, to great ottoman,
He humbly would entreat your majesty
To come and see his homely citadel,
And banquet with him ere thou leavest the I'll.

sp.speaker: Caly.
sp.l: To banquet with him in his citadel,
I fear me, messenger, to feast my train
Within a town of war so lately pillaged,
Will be too costly and too troublesome:
Yet would I gladly visit Barabas.
For well has Barabas deserved of us.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: Selim, for that, thus saith the governor,
That he hath in store a pearl so big,
So precious, and withal so orient,
As be it valued but indifferently,
The price thereof will serve to entertain
Selim and all his soldiers for a month
Therefore he humbly would entreat your highness
Not to depart till he has feasted you.

sp.speaker: Caly.
sp.l: I cannot feast my men in Malta walls,
Except he place his tables in the streets.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: Know, Selim, that there is a monastery
Which standeth as an outhouse to the town;
There will he banquet them, but thee at home,
With all thy pashas and brave followers.

sp.speaker: Caly.
sp.l: Well, tell the governor we grant his suit,
We'll in this summer evening feast with him.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: I shall, my lord,Exit.

sp.speaker: Caly.
sp.l: And now, bold pashas, let us to our tents,
And meditate how we may grace us best
To solemnize our governors great feast. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: In this, my countrymen, be ruled by me,
Have special care that no man sally forth
till you shall hear a culverin discharged
By him that bears the linstock, kindled thus;
Then issue out and come to rescue me,
For happily I shall be in distress,
Or you released of this servitude.

sp.speaker: 1 knight
sp.l: Rather then thus to live as Turkish thralls,
What will we not adventure?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: On then, begone.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.l: Farewell grave governor.

div.stage: Enter with a Hammar above, very busy.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: How stand the cords? How hang these hinges, fast?
Are all the cranes and pulleys sure?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: All fast.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Leave nothing lose, all levelled to my mind.
Why now I see that you have art indeed.
There, carpenters, divide that gold amongst you:
Go swill in bowls of sack and muscadine:
Down to the cellar, taste of all my wines.

sp.speaker: Carpenter
sp.l: We shall, my lord, and thank you:Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And if you like them, drink your fill and die:
For so I live, perish may all the world.
Now Selim-calymath return me word
That thou wilt come, and I am satisfied.
Now sirrah, what, will he come?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: He will; and has commanded all his men
To come ashore, and march through Malta streets,
That thou mayst feast them in thy citadel.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Then now are all things as my wish would have 'em,
There wanteth nothing but the governor's pelf,
And see he brings it: now, governor, the sum.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: With free consent a hundred thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Pounds sayest thou, governor, well since it is no more
I'll satisfy myself with that; nay, keep it still,
For if I keep not promise, trust not me.
And governor, now partake my policy:
first for his army, they are sent before,
Entered the monastery, and underneath
In several places are field-pieces pitched,
Bombards, whole barrels full of gunpowder,
That on the sudden shall dissever it,
And batter all the stones about their ears,
Whence none can possibly escape alive:
Now as for Calymath and his consorts,
Here have I made a dainty gallery,
The floor whereof, this cable being cut,
Doth fall asunder; so that it doth sink
Into a deep pit passed recovery.
Here, hold that knife, and when thou seest he comes,
And with his pashas shall be blithely set,
A warning-piece shall be shot off from the tower,
To give thee knowledge when to cut the cord,
And fire the house; say, will not this be brave?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: O excellent! here, hold thee, Barabas,
I trust thy word, take what I promised thee.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No, governor, I'll satisfy thee first,
Thou shalt not live in doubt of any thing.
Stand close, for here they come: why, is not this
A kingly kind of trade to purchase towns
By treachery, and sell 'em by deceit?
Now tell me, worldlings, underneath the sum,
If greater falsehood ever has been done.

sp.speaker: Caly.
sp.l: Come, my companion-bashawes, see I pray
How busy Barabas is there above
To entertain us in his gallery;
Let us salute him, save thee, Barabas.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Welcome great Calymath.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: How the slave jeers at him?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Will't please thee, mighty Selim-calymath,
To ascend our homely stairs?

sp.speaker: Caly.
sp.l: Ay, Barabas, come pashas, attend.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Stay, Calymath;
for I will show thee greater courtesy
Than Barabas would have afforded thee.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.l: Sound a charge there. A charge, the cable cut, a cauldron discovered.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: How now, what means this

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Help, help me, Christians, help.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: See Calymath, this was devised for thee.

sp.speaker: Caly.
sp.l: Treason, treason pashas, fly.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: No, Selim, do not fly;
See his end first, and fly then if thou canst.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: O help me, Selim, help me, Christians.
Governor, why stand you all so pitiless?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Should I in pity of thy plaints or thee,
Accursed Barabas; base Jew relent:
No, thus I'll see thy treachery repaid,
But wish thou hadst behaved thee otherwise.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You will not help me then?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: No, villain, no.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And villains, know you cannot help me now.
Then Barabas breath forth thy latest fate,
And in the fury of thy torments, strive
To end thy life with resolution:
Know, governor, 'twas I that slew thy son;
I framed the challenge that did make them meet:
Know, Calymath, I aimed thy overthrow,
And had I but escaped this stratagem,
I would have brought confusion on you all,
Damned Christians, dogs, and Turkish infidels;
But now begins the extremity of heat
To pinch me with intolerable pangs:
Die life, fly soul, tongue curse thy fill and die:

sp.speaker: Caly.
sp.l: Tell me, you Christians, what doth this portend?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: This train he laid to have entrapped thy life;
Now Selim note the unhallowed deeds of Jews:
Thus he determined to have handled thee,
But I have rather chose to save thy life.

sp.speaker: Caly.
sp.l: Was this the banquet he prepared for us?
Let's hence, lest further mischief be pretended.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Nay, Selim, stay, for since we have thee here,
We will not let thee part so suddenly:
Besides, if we should let thee go, all's one,
Nor with thy galleys couldst thou not get hence,
Without fresh men to rig and furnish them.

sp.speaker: Caly.
sp.l: Tush, governor, take thou no care for that,
My men are all aboard,
And do attend my coming there by this.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Why heardst thou not the trumpet sound a charge?

sp.speaker: Caly.
sp.l: Yes, what of that?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Why then the house was fired,
Blown up, and all thy soldiers massacred.

sp.speaker: Caly.
sp.l: O monstrous treason!

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: A Jew's courtesy:
For he that did by treason work our fall,
By treason hath delivered thee to us:
Know therefore, till thy father hath made good
The ruins done to Malta and to us,
Thou canst not part: for Malta shall be freed,
Or Selim never return to Ottoman.

sp.speaker: Caly.
sp.l: Nay rather, Christians, let me go to Turkey
In person there to meditate your peace;
To keep me here will naught advantage you.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Content thee, Calymath, here thou must stay,
And live in Malta prisoner; for come cal●●he world
To rescue thee, so will we guard us now
No sooner shall they drink the ocean dry,
Then conquer Malta, or endanger us.
So march away, and let due praise be given
Neither to fate nor fortune, but to heaven.

div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
